title: First Great Western rail workers strike in row over new trains
text:
Rail workers are continuing a 72-hour strike Credit: PA First Great Western rail workers will continue to strike today in a row over new trains.
Members of the RMT union have been staging a 72-hour walkout over a dispute over new Hitachi inter city trains.
Long distance and local services on First Great Western trains will be affected.
Read More: First Great Western workers strike in row over new trains
The union says the issues of the dispute include:
The proposed introduction of Driver Only Operation with door operation procedures to transfer from the Guard to Driver The proposed removal of buffet/restaurant car facilities Despite strenuous and continuing efforts by our negotiators we have not been able to secure the kind of progress we hoped for in the key areas of jobs, services and safety for us to reach an agreement.
The fact remains that if it is good enough for East Coast, using the same trains, to meet the very basic assurances sought by this trade union then it is good enough for First Great Western as well.
– Mick Cash, RMT General Secretary The dispute is over the introduction of new Hitachi inter city trains Credit: PA First Great Western has defended the new trains which it says will deliver more seats, faster journey times and more frequent journeys for our passengers.
These brand new trains will deliver more seats, faster journey times and more frequent journeys for our passengers. Our plans mean more train managers on board our trains, not less.
The key issues remains, that we want the driver to close the doors - which is fundamental to our ability to run the faster, more frequent services customers should expect from a 21st century railway. This method has been used safely across the UK rail industry for decades.
– Mark Hopwood, First Great Western Managing Director The strike is expected to finished at midnight.
Last updated Mon 31 Aug 2015 Travel Wales
